text:
-From the rooftop terrace to
the basement bowling alley,

since arriving in DC, the
new First Family isn't just

changing the rules
of Washington,

it's pulling back the
curtain on the White House.

On Instagram, this
rarely seen view,

Tiffany and Eric Trump standing
on the White House roof.

Ivanka Trump on Inauguration
Day with husband

and presidential
adviser Jared Kushner

and their children in
a presidential limo,
kids in car seats and all.
Experts say it's not surprising.

The Trumps are no strangers
to social media or reality TV.

DONALD TRUMP: Eric, am
I right, or am I wrong?
ERIC TRUMP: No, you're right.
DONALD TRUMP: See, good son.

-But their posts are providing
a public backstage pass

to the presidency
that's rarely been

seen, from inaugural
balls to breakfast
in the State Dining Room.

KATE ANDERSON BROWER:
I am surprised
by how open they're being.

-Kate Anderson
Brower has written

books about first families and
their time in the White House.

KATE ANDERSON BROWER:
Most of those photos

that we've seen from
previous administrations

are taken by professional
White House photographers.
They're very choreographed.

They're really giving you
a behind-the-scenes glimpse

at what life is really
like in the White House.

And in a way, it's making it
really accessible to people.

-The White House has been
photographed for ages,

from the Reagans
to Jackie Kennedy's

televised tour of the residence
she helped redecorate.

During the Obama
administration, the solarium

on the White House
roof was photographed
for architectural digest.

But this week, America
got more candid view--

Eric Trump's wife,
Lara, posting a playful

look at one of the
president's grandchildren
exploring the new digs.

That's an upside down
Donald J. Trump, III.

The caption, "when aunts
and uncles attack."

And in the White
House bowling alley,

that's video of Donald, Jr.'s
wife, Vanessa, in heels.

KATE ANDERSON BROWER: In a way,
it really humanizes the family

like we've never seen
before, taking candid

shots of their kids being
kids and having breakfast

in a Teenage Mutant
Ninja Turtle outfit

and things like that that
are very cute and endearing.

And I almost wonder if part of
it is part of a strategy, too,
to make them likable.

-It's not clear if all
of this online access

is part of a larger media
strategy from a president who

likes to deliver his message
unvarnished on Twitter

or just the results
of a First Family
living in an Instagram age.

Either way, the Trumps are
providing America a new look
at an old institution.
